Like those who first erected the Kol Israel Foundation Holocaust Memorial (@kol_israelcle) six decades ago, we must continue to honor the memory of the Jewish victims who endured unimaginable pain, suffering and loss during the Holocaust.

On Yom HaShoah, we remember the 6 million Jewish victims whose lives were cut tragically short by the Nazi regime.

We also honor the survivors who found refuge across the U.S., including in NE Ohio where they dedicated a memorial in Bedford Heights to all who perished.

I'm incredibly proud of @SeattleFire for the success they've had with this program, and I urge action on my legislation so that we can deploy life-saving crisis response teams like Health One across the country.

That's why I introduced the 911 Diversion to Unarmed Personnel Act, which would provide funding for unarmed 911 response programs that divert nonviolent 911 calls to specialized service providers instead of law enforcement.

The overwhelming majority of 911 calls involve nonviolent, non-criminal incidents that specialized service providers - such as social workers, paramedics, and peer support counselors - are better equipped to handle than armed law enforcement officers.

Health One is a crisis response team comprised of dedicated, trained professionals who are available to provide care for individuals experiencing non-emergency medical or mental health issues. The funding secured will add capacity to this critically important team.

There are countless companies that try to do the right thing, ensuring their products are safe, fixing them when they‚Äôre not (instead of just selling them abroad), and making restitution to those they‚Äôve harmed. That‚Äôs the moral choice and often the right business choice too.

Even if we read reviews and research products, government watchdogs who know what to look for are in a much better position to ensure the products we buy for our families are safe. Americans trust their government to do that and we must ensure agencies are worthy of that trust.

We need meaningful consumer protection and corporate accountability to keep people safe and extract a real cost from those who harm them. Americans try hard to keep their families safe but our government has a duty to help protect them from the dangers they can‚Äôt see coming.

I‚Äôve been continuing in this thread long enough but fundamentally, the news from Johnson & Johnson, both on selling potentially carcinogenic talcum powder as well as the additional reality of its using a bankruptcy loophole to avoid accountability is a reminder‚Ä¶

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm proud to have cosponsored the Nondebtor Release Prohibition Act to close the loophole. This important bill was introduced by @SenWarren @SenatorDurbin @RepJerryNadler @RepMaloney @SenBlumenthal and will bring accountability to misconduct.
https://www.warren.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/warren-nadler-durbin-blumenthal-maloney-announce-legislation-to-eliminate-non-debtor-releases-prevent-corporations-and-private-entities-from-escaping-accountability-in-bankruptcy-proceedings

And Johnson & Johnson isn‚Äôt alone: the Sackler family, owners of Purdue Pharma which knowingly fueled and profited from the opioid epidemic used the same tactic to drastically reduce their liability for the human and financial destruction Purdue caused. https://www.economist.com/united-states/2021/09/09/how-asbestos-saved-the-sackler-family-from-bankruptcy

But how is Johnson & Johnson, a $400 billion company, accepting accountability for the harm that courts have found it‚Äôs knowingly caused to so many women? It‚Äôs not - it‚Äôs using a loophole in bankruptcy law to avoid paying its victims https://www.npr.org/2022/04/02/1082871843/rich-companies-are-using-a-quiet-tactic-to-block-lawsuits-bankruptcy

It‚Äôs a shame that Johnson & Johnson is choosing to still sell a product abroad that it was forced to pull from the shelves in North America because of the number of women it harmed, and the combination of public image and financial costs that resulted.
https://www.reuters.com/legal/government/us-supreme-court-declines-hear-jj-appeal-over-2-billion-baby-powder-judgment-2021-06-01/

This decision and the apparent dismissal of so much research is incredibly disappointing given the dangers of asbestos & how many it‚Äôs harmed: The FDA, WHO, and numerous other public health organizations don‚Äôt accept any level of asbestos in talc as safe. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-health-fda-tal-specialreport-idUSKBN1Y71DE

‚ÄúTwo years later, another executive raised a red flag, saying the company should no longer assume that its talc mines were asbestos-free.
